item.title: Off to Hong Kong again
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_371" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Passengers disembark a Korean Airlines flight from Honolulu International Airport (HNL) at Incheon International Airport (ICN) on Tuesday February 1, 2011 in Seoul, Korea."][/caption] Looks like 2011 is going to be the year of travel for me. :) Headed to Hong Kong (HKG) with my family for Chinese New Years. As with trips to China in the past, we have a layover in Incheon International Airport (ICN). This time, instead of my sister Gwynnelle joining us, my brother Liam will be joining myself and my parents. We won't be staying in HK for too long, roughly a week, as Liam and I need to concentrate on our studies. Please check back here for updates as the days progress. [caption id="attachment_372" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Members of the Nishimura family mull around Gate 14 at Incheon International Airport on Tuesday afternoon, February 1, 2011 in Seoul, Korea."][/caption] We'll also be taking a short jaunt into Shenzen, and hopefully, following my trip to shenzen, I'll be able to meet up with some of the YMCA interns that came from Hong Kong during the Summer. Aloha from Incheon. All Images copyright Kent Nishimura, Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Off to Hong Kong - 2011 Travel Kent Nishimura Photojournalist
On a family vacation, Kent Nishimura a Hawaii based Photojournalist documents his travels in Hong Kong during Chinese New Years.

item.title: Hong Kong Day 1
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_375" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Traffic on Hong Kong Island, February 2, 2011."][/caption] Adjusting to the new time zone has taken quite the toll on our little travelling group. I had about 5 hours of sleep since we had landed, gotten unpacked, arrived at the Hotel, and gotten to bed. 5 hours after all of that, and I found myself awake and on the move, yet again. [caption id="attachment_377" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Liam, my brother, reads a copy of the previous day's Honolulu Star-Advertiser in our parent's room at the Salisbury YMCA on February 2, 2011 in Koloown, Hong Kong."][/caption] First stop. Dim Sum for breakfast. Then it was a half day of touring Hong Kong in our little travel group from Pali Tours. We made our way to a little noodle factory, where between my mom and Chuck Tsui (our travel leader) they must've bought out the entire remaining day's supply of noodles. [caption id="attachment_378" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A woman patiently waits her turn in line for recycling cardboard on Wed. Feb. 2, 2011 in Hong Kong Island."][/caption] The really neat thing about places like Asia, and Hong Kong is the large signs that practically blanket the city. Large signs with awesome bold color make for great backgrounds. [caption id="attachment_379" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="My dad blows on his wonton min in Hong Kong, Hong Kong Island on Wednesday, February 2, 2011."][/caption] We were taken to a "world famous" noodle shop in Hong Kong after purchasing stuff from a dried seafood store. My mom kept raving how No Reservtions' Anthony Bourdain was featured in a magazine article at that shop. After a filling lunch we headed back to the Hotel, The Salisbury YMCA, where we broke into groups and walked around on our own. [caption id="attachment_376" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="We stayed at the Salisbury YMCA, a hotel in Kowloon, again."][/caption] After brief deliberation with my family I decided that I had just about enough of travelling with the group, and wanted to get around on my own. Wanting to get out and be by myself, I decided to hop on the StarFerry to Hong Kong Island from Kowloon, and hunt for picture opportunities there. [caption id="attachment_382" align="aligncenter" width="311" caption="A trio of friends walk along a walkway on Hong Kong Island near the Star Ferry Port."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_380" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Posing for a picture in front of an advertisement on a wall leading into the Harbor City Court shopping mall in Kowloon, Hong Kong."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_383" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A young man loiters in front of a Watch advertisement near the Star Ferry Port in Kowloon, Hong Kong."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_384" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Hong Kong Island as seen from the Star Ferry Port in Kowloon, Hong Kong."][/caption] Fatigue finally caught up with me, and I headed back to the hotel where I went to sleep around 8pm HKST. All Images copyright Kent Nishimura, Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

item.title: Hong Kong Day 3 - Peak Travel
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_430" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Shadows are case in the midday sun on Feb 3, 2011 in Hong Kong Island, Hong Kong."][/caption] We made the trip out to Victoria Peak since Liam, my younger brother, hasnt been thereever. We decided to catch the peak tram up to Victoria Peak, and spend a good chunk of the day up there. The last time I was up there, the Peak Tower was closed and the Peak Tram was undergoing some major maintenance, so it was inaccessible to the general public. We made the mistake of getting off the subway at admiralty station instead of central station, and had to footmobile it up a angry hill. It did provide for some cool photos while we made the trek up to the tram terminal. [caption id="attachment_431" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A man and his son in line at the Peak Tram to Victoria Peak on Hong Kong Island, HK."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_432" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Riding the Peak Tram up to Victoria Peak."][/caption] After the harrowing experience that is riding a tram at a 75 degree angle, we made it to the top. As you can tell from the angle that I shot the last photograph at, I was standing for the duration of the trip. There wasnt a lot of room, and I had given up my seat for an older gentleman (not pictured.) [caption id="attachment_433" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Victoria Peak Visitors are cast in silhouette by backlight at the Peak Tower on Thurs. Feb 3, 2011 in Hong Kong."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_434" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Victoria Peak Visitors are framed by Lai See hanging on a tree at the Peak tower on Thurs. Feb 3, 2011 in Hong Kong."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_435" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="My dad and his map, trying to find out way back to the Subway station."][/caption] All Images copyright Kent Nishimura, Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Kent Nishimura is a Hawaii based Photojournalist travelling in Hong Kong during Chinese New Years with his family.

item.title: Hong Kong Day 4 - Kung Hei Fat Choy
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_479" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Guests pack the rooftop of the Salisbury YMCA for the viewing of the Lunar New Year fireworks show on Fri. Feb 4, 2011 in Kowloon, Hong Kong."][/caption] Kung Hei Fat Choy! Even though being Chinese, and having parents that strongly encouraged the cultural practices of our heritage, I had never seen the celebration of the Lunar New Year to be as big of a deal as January 1. Probably cause I would get to blow shit up. In China, the Luar New Year goes out with all the Pomp and Circumstance as any other country celebrates the regular new years. There was a massive parade complete with floats, a 10 million dollar (HKD) fireworks show, and to top it all off everything was fricken closed!!! doh! As apart of our tour package, we had the New Years' buffet at the Salisbury YMCA (hotel we're staying at) and got to witness the fireworks show from the YMCA's Roof. [caption id="attachment_480" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Fireworks appear to be Blooming Bokeh when the focus is shifted."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_481" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A packed rooftop at the Salisbury YMCA for the viewing of the Lunar New Year fireworks."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_482" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Bokeh'd Fireworks"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_483" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="People file away from the Cultural Center, which is right on Victoria Harbor after viewing the Lunar New Year fireworks show on Fri. Feb 4, 2011 in Kowloon, Hong Kong."][/caption] All Images copyright Kent Nishimura, Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Kent Nishimura is a photojournalist based in Hawaii. He blogs about his travel to Hong Kong during Chinese New Years 2011.
Chinese New Year Fireworks Show in Hong Kong - Blog

item.title: Human Planet - BBC
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_428" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A BBC audio slideshow by Timothy Allen."][/caption] I usually blog about my own photos here, and It's rare that I blog about anything else.  But I figured why not, I should share some thoughts about an audio slideshow that was shared with me.  The other day, I was shared this link by Kim Baxter, Kim is a professor at Kapiolani Community College, where she teaches communications.  I'm currently enrolled in her Newswriting class.

A joint production of Discovery and the BBC, the Human Planet television series travels to eighty of the most remote locations on Earth to find stories about man's remarkable relationship with the natural world.  Timothy Allen was the photographer assigned to shadow the film crew as they spent almost 2 years working on this project.

It's an amazing body of work, with great moments in great light; it takes an intimate look into many of the worlds indigenous cultures still trying to make it on this planet.  Amazing work. It's a 8 minute slide show, you should check it out! Click on the screen grab of the website or click here.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Kent Nishimura, a Hawaii based Photojounalist talks about the BBC's Human Planet featuring a slideshow of Images by Professional Photographer Timothy Allen

item.title: Lights Out
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_349" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Thunderstorm clouds gather over Manoa in Honolulu, Hawaii."][/caption] A thunderstorm knocked out power in East Honolulu for hours on May 2, 2011. Power was later restored, but not after a torrential downpour in Manoa. The residents of the Atherton YMCA had to deal with no lights and no power in their small college dormitory. Lit by only a handful of battery operated lanterns, and fed by the Blue Truck Teppanyaki Wagon, they hung out and kept each other company through the night. [caption id="attachment_355" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Staff and residents of the Atherton YMCA Dormitory gather in the lobby after the power went out in East Honolulu."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_350" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A line forms at the Blue Teppanyaki Truck outside of the Atherton YMCA after power went out in East Honolulu."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_352" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A funnel cloud forms just off shore of the Kakaako District in Honolulu, Hawaii on May 2, 2011."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_353" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Residents mull around the lobby of the Atherton YCMCA during a power outage."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_351" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Chino Cabalteja examines Brian Almanza's head by flashlight after he returned to the dormitory with a head injury. This proved difficult as the YMCA's first aid resources were finite, and there was no electricity available."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_354" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Martin Quitigua sits in the Atherton YMCA lobby after running out into the heavy rain pour to assist in closing windows to prevent water from flooding the YMCA's lobby on May 2, 2011 in Honolulu, Hawaii."][/caption] All Images copyright Kent Nishimura, Honolulu HI based photojournalist | www.kentnishimura.net

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A storm knocked out power in east honolulu, including Manoa, where the 80 resident Atherton YMCA Dorm is located. REsidents were without power for a few hours.
Storm knocks out Power in East Honolulu

item.title: Toro Nagashi
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_371" align="aligncenter" width="650" caption="Volunteers hold lanterns as they get prepared to set them out to open water at Ala Moana Beach Park during the 13th Annual Lantern Floating in Honolulu, Hawaii."][/caption] Every year Shinnyo-En Hawaii, and the Na Lei Aloha Foundation come together to host a Lantern Floating Festival held on Memorial Day. Lantern floating is an Asian spiritual tradition that beautifully symbolizes the wish for all beings to live in peaceful coexistence. As the lanterns are released onto the ocean they take with them written prayers and/or messages for victims of conflict, famine, disaster and disease as well as hopes for the happiness of all past and present. The event is sponsored by Na Lei Aloha Foundation and officiated by the Shinnyo-en Buddhist sect. More photographs after the jump. [caption id="attachment_372" align="aligncenter" width="640" caption="People wait in line to recieve a lantern at Ala Moana Beach Park during the 13th Annual Lantern Floating in Honolulu, Hawaii."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_373" align="aligncenter" width="333" caption="A woman wipes tears after the start of the 13th Annual Lantern Floating ceremony on Memorial Day in Honolulu, HI."][/caption] All Images copyright Kent Nishimura, Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Kent Nishimura documented moments at the 2011 Lantern Floating at Ala Moana Beach Park. Held by the Shinnyo-en and Na Lei Aloha Foundation.
2011 Lantern Floating, Honolulu, HI - Toro Nagashi

item.title: Barnstorm, The Eddie Adams Workshop
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: In October I will be joining 99 other students in Jeffersonville, NY for Barnstorm XXIV, the Eddie Adams Workshop. The Eddie Adams Workshop is an intense, tuition-free, four-day gathering of the top photography professionals, along with 100 carefully selected students. Stoked to be going along with Joel Hawksley, Drew Angerer, Maddie McGarvey, Thomas Simonnetti, and so many other talented photographers. Stay tuned to the blog for more posts as EAW2011 closes in.

item.title: Relay for Life
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_391" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Relay for Life participants walk around a track made up of Luminaries at the 2011 Relay for Life at Magic Island on July 16, 2011 in Honolulu, Hawaii"][/caption] Spent my Saturday-Sunday at the The 2011 American Cancer Society Relay For Life at Magic Island. The relay gives people in communities across the globe a chance to celebrate the lives of people who have battled cancer, remember loved ones lost, and fight back against the disease. At a Relay event, teams of people camp out at a local high school, park, or fairground and take turns walking or running around a track or path. Each team is asked to have a representative on the track at all times during the event. Because cancer never sleeps, Relays are overnight events up to 24 hours in length.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 2011 Relay for Life at Magic Island

item.title: Haleiwa Bon Festival
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_469" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A volunteer helps set lanters out to open waters on Saturday, July 23, 2011 at the Haleiwa Jodo Mission Bon Dance and Toro Nagashi (Lantern Floating) on the North Shore of Oahu in Haleiwa, Hawaii"][/caption] Yesterday, I made the long hour drive out to Oahu's North Shore to the Historic Haleiwa Town for the Haleiwa Jodo Mission's Bon Festival. The Festival, held during Obon Season, featured a Bon Dance, Food, Hapi Coats, Yukatas, and a Toro Nagashi. Obon is a Japanese Buddhist custom to honor the departed spirits of one's ancestors. This Buddhist custom, which has been celebrated in Japan for more than 500 years, has evolved into a family reunion holiday during which people return to ancestral family places and the spirits of ancestors are supposed to revisit the household altars. At the beginning of Obon Season, I covered a Toro Nagashi, or Lantern Floating, officiated by the Shinnyo-en buddhist sect and put on by the Na Lei Aloha Foundation. http://goo.gl/2C5gL [caption id="attachment_475" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A moment of silence at the Haleiwa Obon festival at the Haleiwa Jodo Mission."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_470" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A woman pauses between songs on Saturday, July 23, 2011 at the Haleiwa Jodo Mission Bon Dance and Toro Nagashi (Lantern Floating) on the North Shore of Oahu in Haleiwa, Hawaii"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_471" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Kids on Saturday, July 23, 2011 at the Haleiwa Jodo Mission Bon Dance and Toro Nagashi (Lantern Floating) on the North Shore of Oahu in Haleiwa, Hawaii"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_472" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A little girl who didn't want to be apart from her mother who was playing the flute at the yagura, a high wooden scaffold, on Saturday, July 23, 2011 at the Haleiwa Jodo Mission Bon Dance and Toro Nagashi (Lantern Floating) on the North Shore of Oahu in Haleiwa, Hawaii"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_473" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Lanterns are set out to open waters on Saturday, July 23, 2011 at the Haleiwa Jodo Mission Bon Dance and Toro Nagashi (Lantern Floating) on the North Shore of Oahu in Haleiwa, Hawaii"][/caption] All Images copyright Kent Nishimura, Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

item.title: A rangefinder, a roll of film ,and a beautiful day
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_486" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A couple at Kakaako Waterfront Park. Shot on Fuji Superia400 shot on a Leica M3 with Summicron 50mm f/2, May 25, 2011 in Honolulu, HI."][/caption] I had privilege of borrowing a Leica M3 from my friend, and fellow photographer, Shawn Fields. Soon after having some coffee with him, I rushed home to drop in a roll of Fuji Superia 400, and get shooting. For those looking for good film in Hawaii, I recommend going to ImageWorks. Hawaii Photo Rental is also there, so if you need film, and are interested in renting some toys you can't afford to buy, and you wanna try it out it's the one stop shop to go to! Using a rangefinder is different from a slr. I like that I get to see..."outside the box." I might see something I might normally miss while using SLRs. All Images copyright Kent Nishimura, Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

item.title: Graduation time again
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_498" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="A woman gets up from her seat during the Maryknoll School Commencement Exercises at the Blaisdell Concert Hall in Honolulu, Hawaii"][/caption] Yeppers! It's that time of year again. Graduations. Sadly I've been a bit forgetful when it comes to graduations. I've been a bit negligent, and have missed a bunch of graduations already. :( I only had a Fuji X100 last night; I've only had this little camera for a short time, but I'm totally sold on its low-light capabilities! Whoa! Congrats to all the graduates! May you accomplish your dreams! All Images copyright Kent Nishimura, Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

item.title: Kuru Kuru Sushi open in Kahala!!!!
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_501" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Negihamachi, Maguro Nigiri, and Poke Nigiri go around on the conveyor belt at the newly opened Kuru-Kuru Sushi restaurant in Kahala Mall."][/caption] One of my all time favorite Kaiten Sushi (conveyor-belt sushi) places has opened up shop near my place of work and school! Kuru-Kuru Sushi has opened up a shop at Kahala Mall. Kuru-Kuru is one of many Kaiten Sushi establishments in Hawaii. There are other pretenders to the throne, Genki Sushi, G-Sushi, and Sushi-San, but Kuru-Kuru beats out the competition with their reasonable prices, good quality fish, and generous portions. item.title: Scenes from Charlotte
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: It's been a couple days since I arrived in Charlotte, NC on vacation to visit Geena. Charlotte is a lovely city, and the East Coast provides with some amazing light during golden hour. Looking forward to spending more time around the city and checking out more sights and scenes. More after the Jump All Images Kent Nishimura, a Honolulu, HI based Photojournalist | www.kentnishimura.com

item.title: Summer Redux
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_518" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Nix Kinney of Honolulu sunbathes at Fort DeRussy beach park in Waikiki, Hawaii."][/caption] Summer is over, and Fall has arrived. The fall semester has started and people are headed back to school. Dreams of summer waft in the wind as the seasons change and friends head off to school, once again, or for the first time. Everyone embarking on new adventures. But, It's still really, really hot every day here in Hawaii Still feels like summer time.

item.title: The Red Carpet and the Sunset on the Beach
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_524" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Terry O'Quinn greets fans from the Red Carpet of the screening of the premiere of "Hawaii 5-0" Season 2 at Sunset on the Beach on September 10, 2011 in Waikiki, Hawaii."][/caption] Spent the better part of an afternoon at Waikiki Beach just near the Kapahulu Groin. There, the iconic sunset on the beach screen, would thousands of spectators see the world premiere of Hawaii 5-0's second season. I was called by Getty Images' entertainment desk in LA, for photos from the red carpet; I agreed to cover it for them. Above is an outtake of Terry O'Quinn greeting fans along the red carpet. What a classy guy. All Images copyright Kent Nishimura/Getty Images, a Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

item.title: The Faces of Hawaii Five-0
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_533" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Grace Park attends the screening of season 2 of Hawaii Five-0 at Sunset on the Beach"][/caption] Hawaii Five-0 is a police procedural drama that returns for a second season on September 19. A re-imagining of the original 19681980 television series, the new "5-0" is set in the modern day, with Alex O'Loughlin as Commander Steve McGarrett. For more information on the series check out CBS's 5-0 website. More images of the actors after the jump. Like i mentioned in my last post, I covered the arrival of the stars for Getty Entertainment. I covered the arrival of the season one world premiere a year earlier. The images from season one are available on the Kent Nishimura Photoshelter Archive for viewing. This year was a bit different, a bit better organized, and as always I had a good time. Hung out with the Star-Advertiser's Cindy Ellen Russell, Mark Arbeit who was shooting for Pacific Basin Communications, Lucy Pemoni who was shooting for WireImage, and my favorite photog couple, husband and wife duo Ed White and Dallas Nagata-White who were shooting for NonStop Honolulu. [caption id="attachment_529" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="The Star-Advertiser's Cindy Ellen Russell and freelancer Aaron Yoshino."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_528" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Some people were waiting at Waikiki Beach from 10am in the morning."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_541" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Photographers crowd infront of a photo wall as they wait for the stars to arrive"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_540" align="aligncenter" width="700" caption="Honolulu Mayor Peter Carslile is seen on stage at sunset on the beach while Hawaii Governor Neil Abercrombie reads a declaration."][/caption] Mahalo for stopping through! All Images copyright Kent Nishimura/Getty Images, a Honolulu HI based photographer | www.kentnishimura.net

item.title: Dispatch from New York
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: At the "1130 Club" students are able to share their work with Editors from the New York Times, TIME Magazine, Newsweek, The Associated Press, Getty Images and more. Living in the middle of the Pacific doesnt afford me the opportunity to attend a lot of workshops regularly, but when I had found out that I had indeed been accepted to Barnstorm XXIV, the Eddie Adams workshop, I immediately booked my plane tickets. While I cant compare Barnstorm to other photo workshops like the Missouri or Mountain Workshops, its been perhaps the most unique, amazing experience of my life so far. Many friends told me that Barnstorm this magical workshop where they met amazing people and lasting friendships were forged, but as I found out this past weekend, that was just the tip of the iceberg. My good friend Cory Lum was the first to introduce me to the idea of applying to the workshop. Hes an 1993 alumni of the workshop, from the blue team with Chris Hondros, Alex Garcia, and Ami Vitale. One day over beers, he suggested I apply for the workshop. Its an amazing experience. Itll blow your mind he said. After two years of getting rejection letters, I finally got it. I received word during lunch with my girlfriend via a text message from my friend Patrick Fallon. You got in to Eddie Adams! he wrote. In the middle of the crowded restaurant, I jumped up from my seat and started cheering at the top of my lungs; people stopped eating and awkwardly stared at me, but I didnt care. For those of you who dont know who Eddie Adams is, or what the Barnstorm Workshop is, Eddie Adams (1933-2004) was a Pulitzer Prize winning photojournalist who covered 13 wars and was recognized with over 500 awards during his lifetime. He founded the Workshop along with his wife Alyssa, who still allows students into her home and continues the tradition of Eddies vision. Every year, the workshop selects 50 students, and 50 just starting-out professionals for an intensive four day workshop in Jeffersonville, NY. Fast forward to October 7, 2011. From across the world, 100 students from all walks of photography photojournalism, portraiture, sports photography, commercial studio work, and more descended upon Jeffersonville, NY for the workshop. On the ride up to the Catskills, we talked about what type of photography each of us pursued, and where we were from. We shared out expectations of the workshop, and whom we hoped to get a chance to meet. But nothing, and I mean absolutely nothing could have prepared me for the walk up the hill; being cheered on by hundreds of faculty, staff, and volunteers all of whose goal was giving each and every student the experience of a lifetime. Each day after the first was better and better. In what seemed like an extremely short four days, we were able to listen and learn about the the latest work and ideas coming out of Sports Illustrated from Jimmy Colton and Steve Fine; soon after we were listening to Eugene Richards speak about his experiences during work on long term projects, Doug Menuez speak about photographing Steve Jobs, post-Apple in the mid 80s and listening to Bill Eppridge tell his story about his time following Robert F. Kennedy on the campaign trail. My favorite speech, was from Red Team Leader and New York Times Staff Photographer Todd Heisler. Todd spoke mainly about two bodies of work, first was his famous Pulitzer-Prize winning essay, Final Salute from his time at the Rocky Mountain News, he spent a year documenting the work of Major Steve Beck and the Marine Honor Guard who handle family notifications and the funerals of Marines killed during the Iraq War. The second was a project that the New York Times conducted in 2009 called One in 8 Million where Todd and other staff from the Times profiled 54 New Yorkers every week for a little over year. The series won a News and Documentary Emmy Award in 2010. Todd spoke about the impact the projects had upon him, and how they shaped the way he grew as a photographer. Probably the most difficult thing about the workshop was that there were so many things to do and experience, but just not enough time in the day for what we were trying to accomplish. Aside from the speakers, for a good majority of the weekend students worked on completing a documentary essay structured around their teams theme. It was a good opportunity for students to work on deadline, and with extremely skilled editors. It was normal for students to finish for the day and get back to the hotel around 2 oclock in the morning, only having to wake up four hours later. You will sleep when you are dead, or at the end of this workshop. said Stacy Pearsall, my team leader during our first team meeting at Eddies farm. We all laughed nervously because deep down, we all knew she was right. My team, the Lilac Team, had the theme of Talent between the Ten of us, we each photographed a person in the town of Sullivan and did our best to find and tell a story about who they are and what their talents are. Each story was thoroughly researched by our teams producer, New York based Leah Latella. I got to spend my time photographing Ramona Jan of Damascus, Pennsylvania who lived along the Delaware river. Ramona owns a store called Vintage Bling and aside from selling vintage clothes and jewelry, she made lamps from recycled antiques and ceramic doll heads. I spent a nice chunk of my first shooting day getting Ramona accustomed to me being there, I wanted her to eventually think of me as just another item in her studio where she made her lamps. A fly on the wall if you will. Being a fly on the wall would allow her to open up and not act any certain type of way, allowing me to capture who she really is. It was very cool being able to watch the physical manifestation of her creative process at work while she assembled, disassembled and re-assembled the lamp she was working on, only to disassemble it again. After shooting, editing, and listening to speakers, students were able to get their work reviewed by editors and photographers from many different newspapers, magazines, and agencies at the 1130 club. I got to meet and show my work to Patrick Witty of TIME, Sandy Ciric, Pierce Wright, Michael Heiman and Mario Tama of Getty Images, Diana Suryakusuma of Bloomberg Business week, and Jimmy Colton of Sports Illustrated to name a few. Todd Heisler, Jimmy Colton, Leah Latella, Jamie Wellford and my teammates gave me the support I needed throughout the weekend, and really put a lot of things into perspective for me. Where my work needed improvement, and helped me realize that I dont need to move from Hawaii to pursue storiesjust yet. But, beyond my work, and what i needed to do to improve, I realized that I had become a part of something bigger than all of us, I made friendships and connections with people from across the world all of whom I am proud to know, and call them Ohana. This post originally appeared as a part of a post on the NPPA Student Blog, The Visual Student.

item.title: #OccupyWallSt
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: Occupy Wall Street protestors and union members stage a protest near Wall Street in New York, October 5, 2011. The demonstrators are protesting bank bailouts, foreclosures and high unemployment from their encampment in the financial district of New York City. Made my way down to Wall Street yesterday to get a feel for whats going on with "Occupy Wall Street." The "Occupy" movement has been growing legs and moving across the globe. What I found interesting is that for a group, they are extremely organized and are utilizing social media and technology to their advantage. Yesterday, they marched from Zucotti Park, a privately owned park in lower Manhattan to City Hall. I wish I could spend more time documenting what happens, but I'll be off to the Catskills for Barnstorm XXIV. :) So excited! I can't wait! More images after the jump Occupy Wall Street protestors and union members stage a protest near Wall Street in New York, October 5, 2011. Occupy Wall Street protestors gather for a general assembly at Zucotti Park on October 5, 2011. EDIT (October 10, 2011): Brookfield Office Properties, the owners of Zuccotti Park, issued a statement saying "Sanitation is a growing concern ... Normally the park is cleaned and inspected every weeknight... because the protestors refuse to cooperate ... the park has not been cleaned since Friday, September 16th and as a result, sanitary conditions have reached unacceptable levels." To protect and clean the park, protesters have been volunteering to sweep the areas of the plaza and post signs urging each other to avoid damaging the flower beds. **All Images Kent Nishimura, Honolulu, HI based Photojournalist**

item.title: APEC is coming...
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: Gaye Chan, a professor at the University of Hawaii defaces a sign welcoming the upcoming APEC summit on Bachman Lawn at the University of Hawaii at Manoa Campus on October 26, 2011 in Honolulu, Hawaii. APEC is right around the corner, and it's seriously going to keep my occupied for most of that week. APEC, or the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, is a hot button topic for some especially with the rise of the #Occupy Movements around the world. There are those who believe that APEC is bad and evil because the little guy gets tossed in the poop shoot and left to hang out to dry in the wind. Yesterday, a group made up of 15-20 people marched along the McCarthy Mall at the University of Hawaii at Manoa campus voicing their opposition to a sign placed at the front of the campus welcoming APEC to Hawaii. The protesters believe that the welcoming of APEC doesn't represent the full view of the entire university community, and they wanted it taken down. Protesters gather outside of Bachman Hall, where the offices of M.R.C. Greenwood are located on the University of Hawaii at Manoa Campus on October 26, 2011 in Honolulu. Wether or not it's bad, It's going to be my job for four days to cover protests and possibly riots in and around Honolulu as the days count down to the APEC CEO Summit and Plenary meetings. I, along with my fellow Honolulu freelance photojournalist, Eugene Tanner will be apart of a 15 man team that Agence France-Presse will covering APEC with. During my last two days of APEC duty, I will be working in the White House Travel Pool along side my good friend Cory Lum, who will be working in the International Pool providing coverage for all. All images Kent Nishimura a Honolulu, HI based Photojournalist | www.kentnishimura.com

item.title: Angry Christians Redux
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: A few years back, there was a group from the "Cry-to-god Ministries" that secured a permit to utilize the Hemenway Courtyard for free-speech. The group then proceeded to antagonize the student body, in an attempt to engage with them about their spirituality through confrontation. Some of will you will remember that there was a lot of coverage from Ka Leo back when they showed up in March 2009. http://goo.gl/Xm1Zb. They showed up this year at UH Manoa, but since Campus Center is currently under construction, they held their rally/protest/whatever it is outside Manoa Gardens, the campus watering hole. Great, lets mix beer, college kids and people who call the aforementioned college kids whores, heathans, sinners and a whole mess of other not-so-nice names. But, of course, it gave me a brief opportunity to make pictures once again. This time however, there wasn't much of a crowd worth speaking of; But, since it's Halloween, a UH student, Thomas Plate, showed up as Jesus. Click the link to view this gallery on Photoshelter Archive. All Images 2011Honolulu, HI Based Photojournalist Kent Nishimura | www.kentnishimura.net

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great coverage, Kent! Lots of emotion and action happening. Unlike the *cough* UH-paper...

item.title: A day that will live in Infamy...
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: A Marine firing detail prepares for a memorial service for the 70th anniversary of the attack on the U.S. naval base at Pearl Harbor on the island of Oahu on December 7, 2011 in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. On the morning of December 7, 1941 a surprise military attack was conducted by aircraft of the Imperial Japanese Navy against the U.S. Pacific Fleet being moored in Pearl Harbor becoming a major catalyst for the United States entering World War II. I was lucky growing up; my parents believe that a deep understanding of my cultural heritage was essential to me growing up into a well rounded young man. Perhaps one of the more important things my mom stressed besides cultural understanding was that of an understanding of history and paying attention to not only every day details, but details that have happened throughout history itself. "Those who do not learn from history, are doomed to repeat it..." is what she and my father would always say. Early on in my childhood I learned a lot about World War II and the impact it had upon the people of the islands and the world. More so especially the impact upon Americans and Asian-Americans alike. I read Jeanne Wakatsuki Houston's "Farewell to Manzanar", and started to connect the dots with what my father and his siblings (who were just young children during the war) had gone through. Well nothing as severe as Manzanar, but something along those lines. It wasn't until I got older that I began to understand the toll war would take upon a country, its soliders, their families and communities. The first Iraq War raged on while I was in kindergarten. I vaguely remember trying yellow ribbons onto the fence at my elementary school, somehow 'supporting our troops.' Questions started to pop into my head. What was it like for the veterans of the current war. being fought in Iraq. Scenes of the bombing of Baghdad flashed through my mind's eye. If this is what was happening during the Gulf War, what must've those sailors and soliders have gone through during the bombing of Pearl Harbor?? I mean, It was, after all, a surprise attack by the Japanese. In my younger day's I read a lot. I read about the attack on pearl harbor, and i would scour old newsmagazines and history books looking at photographs of war in the pacific theater. For as long as I could remember, I wanted to visit the USS Arizona Memorial and the Bowfin museum. In the Spring of 1996 I would get my first chance to visit the National Monument. Much to my dismay however there was a massive oil spill in the Waiau Stream and into Pearl Harbor, making it impossible for my class to get out to the memorial. It wasn't for a long time, that I would be able to make it out to the memorial... Fast forward to almost fifteen years to December of last year, where I photographed the the 69th Anniversary the Attack on Pearl Harbor for Getty Images. It gave me an opportunity to not only just revisit part of my youth but in some ways for me to come to an understanding with everything I had learned and everything I knew at that point in time. For me, having been born to Generation Y, and not having living remotely close to the time of the Great Depression and World War II, outside of photographs and old movie clips I had no idea what it was like that fateful December morning. Seeing the grizzly veterans, now past their prime, clad in colorful aloha shirts it seemed almost surreal being able to observe them, and be able to interact with them. The things some of them must have been through, the places they had been, and the events that unfolded in front of their very eyes...their individual stories floating around in the ethereal consciousness of their collective memories, waiting...waiting to be told. Many quite moments were to be found in at the memorial itself last year, especially in the shrine room. This year, however, was a little different. Sadly, the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association is disbanding at the end of the 2011 calendar year. With the numbers of survivors dwindling it was the logical choice for the association to make. Check out some selects from this years December 7 ceremony below. Tim Greene (L) shares a laugh with Pearl Harbor Survivor Delton Walling (C) and Joan Bohl (R) before a memorial service for the 70th anniversary of the attack on the U.S. naval base at Pearl Harbor on the island of Oahu on December 7, 2011 in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Pearl Harbor Survivors Association Vice President Mal Middlesworth salutes during a memorial service for the 70th anniversary of the attack on the U.S. naval base at Pearl Harbor on the island of Oahu on December 7, 2011 in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. A marine firing detail stand at attention with the Arizona Memorial in background. U.S.S. Arizona Survivor Lou Conter and daughter Louann Daley exit the Arizona Memorial. **All Images 2011 Honolulu, HI Based Photojournalist Kent Nishimura and Getty Images**

item.title: It's that time of year again...
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: US President Barack Obama waves as he disembarks from Air Force One at Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam in Honolulu, Hawaii, Friday, Dec. 23, 2010. So It's that time of year again. The President is chillin in his swanky vacation rental in Kailua and my winter break is pretty much booked. But who am I to complain? (I think it's just the photographer in me. We complain about everything.) I have my health, I have work, and I'm photographing the leader of the free world. How awesome is that?? So as with previous years past, I was working for the Independent Still Pool -- rotating days with fellow photojournalist and good friend Cory Lum. POTUS arrived in the early evening at Hickam Air Force base where he motorcaded out to Kailua, picked up Mrs. O, and the subsequently headed to dinner at Morimoto Waikiki. Of course, the Pool never saw him... Stay Tuned, more to come... Air Force One is seen making its approach to Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam on December 23, 2011. US President Barack Obama waves as he crosses the tarmac from Air Force One to greet well-wishers at Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam in Honolulu, Hawaii. **All photographs copyright Kent Nishimura and Bloomberg News**

item.title: I gotta hand it to you...
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: Eight month old Cooper Wall Wagner sticks his fingers in President Barack Obama's mouth as he poses for a picture with Cooper's parents Greg, right, and Meredith Wagner in Kaneohe, Hawaii, Dec. 25. The President and Mrs. Obama made their annual trip to greet current and retired members of the US military and their families and ate a Christmas Day meal in the Anderson Hall mess hall at Marine Corps Base Hawaii. So the frame above this is quite funny. But let me get to it...thats right folks...it's Story Time with Kent! Bear with me, as I've found it quite fun to ramble on in my blog posts. Seriously though, it's been a crazy couple of days. First night of POTUS's vacation in Hawaii, he went ahead and deviated fromt eh norm. Typically with POTUS arrivals he'll jet from Hickam to Kailua, and the 'travel pool' will get a lid, which allows us to go home. Come Christmas morning, as I found myself not caring that there were some gifts with my name on them wrapped underneath the tree, nor the fact that my mom was preparing an awesome christmas meal for the rest of the family's breakfast, I slung my cameras over my shoulders and headed, with my pops in tow, out the door...the bass heavy beat of dub-step stomped it's way through the air as I walked out the door. But wait?! What's this? It's dub-step CHRISTMAS MUSIC?! "Today's gonna kick ass." I told myself. The day started out like any other Pool day for me, meet at the Westin, Go to Kailua, get swept...and then...play what I call, the waiting game. Upon receiving news of a 'movement', the pool got ready to joing POTUS's motorcade and head with him...well...to whereever he was going. (They never tell us what's happening. It's like I said earlier today -- 12/26/2011 -- The press bus is the creepy drunk uncle that comes to family gatherings, the one that no one wants him at. As POTUS's black suburban whips past the press bus you hear shutters fire. *snap* Nail'd the obligatory Motorcade photo, through the ugly green tinted bullet proof glass. Next? We're going to church! US President Barack Obama, First Lady Michelle Obama and daughters Malia and Sasha Obama enter the Marine Corps Base Hawaii Chapel in Kaneohe, Hawaii, Sunday, December 25, 2011. On the way back from Chruch we entered the 'protected zone' along Kailuana Place, where the President's Vacation Rental home is...along the way, we spotted Eric Riseberg, a Staffer with the Associated Press out of San Francisco. Lukcy for AP, Audrey McAvoy's,one of their Hawaii Staff writer, mother lives along the same street. I call it the AP Press Hold. After a very very long wait...which seemed like an eternity, we followed POTUS off back to the Marine Corps Base. As with past years, he and Mrs. O went to do their annual meet and greet with soliders at the base mess hall. Members of the US military and their families take pictures of US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama during a Christmas Day visit to Anderson Hall mess hall at Marine Corps Base Hawaii on Sunday, December 25, 2011 in Kaneohe, Hawaii. This is where the little baby dude went ahead and shoved his hand up POTUS's nose and into POTUS's mouth. Quite the hilarious moment. TOTALLY MADE MY DAY! On the way back to Waikiki, there was some amazing light going over the Pali. It was beautiful. A great way to end a pretty cool day. **All Images 2011 Kent Nishimura and Corbis/Independent Still Pool**

item.title: New York City again
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: People walk along 8th Avenue fronting The New York Times building is seen on October 4, 2011 in New York, NY. Its been a year since I visited New York City. Last time, it was just to visit my good friend Chad Hiu, a director at the International YMCA. This year, of course was for the Eddie Adams Workshop. Walking along 8th Avenue, I found myself standing in front of The New York Times building. I am currently a freelancer for the National Desk in Honolulu, HI. Its my dream job to be a staffer with the times. Time to hit the hay, its 11:45pm here in NY, and I have to get an early start tomorrow.

item.title: Eddie Adams WorkshopXXIV: Day 1
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: First off, lemme say HOLY CRAP that was frickin amazing!!!!! I heard stories about walking up the hill to the farm, but nothing, NOTHING could've prepared me for that. Amamzing!!! Furthermore...Eugene Richards was the nights keynote speaker...AMAZING! Collected here are some scenes from my first day at the 24th Eddie Adams Workshop. It's crazy late, and I have a long day ahead of me. Just waiting for my roommate, Andy Spear, to fall asleep so my snoring doesn't keep him awake. For updates as the day progresses check out my twitter feed: @kentnish or follow this hashtag: #eaw. More images after the jump. All photos Kent Nishimura - Honolulu, HI based Photojournalist | www.kentnishimura.com

item.title: Clear Sunset
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: Clear as the eye can see. Far as the eye can see, not a cloud in the sky. This past weekend, I headed out to Kakaako Waterfront Park in search of some features in some golden hour light.

item.title: Pro Bowl 2012
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: Patrick Peterson #21 of the Arizona Cardinals intercepts a pass meant for A.J. Green #18 of the Cincinnati Bengals during the 2012 NFL Pro Bowl at Aloha Stadium on January 29, 2012 in Honolulu, Hawaii. The 2012 Pro Bowl has come and gone, and with the upcoming Rematchbowl...I mean Super Bowl XLVI no one really cares about nor tried hard at the Pro Bowl. It was my first football game in awhile, but it was a lot of fun working along side Marco, Eugene, Hugh, Jay, Jamm and Scott. Good times! More Images after the break. The full edit of images can be viewed at gettyimages.com **All Images Copyright Kent Nishimura/Getty Images**

item.title: Hidden Gem
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded:
Members of the NFC team walk on field during the 2012 NFL Pro Bowl at Aloha Stadium on January 29, 2012 in Honolulu, HI.
Living the in the world of tight-deadline news (especially if you are filing on east-coast deadline and you're in Hawaii), photographers are forced to edit their entire take onsite. Most of the time we'll send 95% of our best of the best work for the wire or for the paper, but sometimes we miss something. A cool image gets lost in the shuffle of image downloading, color correcting in ACR, cursing up a storm because our air cards don't work, cursing up a storm because 7 different photographers are trying to transmit images, but someone's hogging all the bandwidth...or it's just everyone in the workroom teasing Marco. When shooting a sports assignment for Getty Images, photographers are instructed to file a '2nd Edit' of images. Included in the second edit is any game action the photographer may have missed in the first edit, as well as isolated stock imagery of star players. While going through my entire edit of photos from the 2012 Pro Bowl, I came across this hidden gem. While it wasn't key action, or a photo of a single player, I thought it was some really pretty light. In the next couple of weeks I'll be posting blog posts about workflow and some of the stuff I do as a photojournalist. Thanks for looking. **All Images 2012 Kent Nishimura/Getty Images**

item.title: Bored Much?
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: While waiting outside of the Legal Service Center at Marine Corps Base Hawaii while On Assignment for The Associated Press, I saw that there was something pretty cool happening with the reflection in the window we (the media) had to stand behind...why were we standing behind the window and not in front of the courtroom? Trust me, that's a whole another can of worms... Can anyone spot the Star-Advertiser's Craig Kojima?

item.title: Fire in the Sky
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: On my way to work at the YMCA, as I was leaving the house I noticed a strange light pattern in the sky. The clouds were formed strangely, and were lit funkily with the rising sun. I put my camera in the front seat, making it readily accessible just in case I changed my mind on photographing the sky today on my way to work. Good thing. heading down the H1, I came across this wonderful sight. Amazing.

item.title: Mark III
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded:
Canon ruined my weekend. It wasn't from lack of customer service, or that I had a camera crap out on me whilst on assignment. Nor was it because a Camera body I had was defective. It was something entirely different. There I was, minding my own business while editing photos, and prepping them for my photoshelter achive, and a post from Josh at Hawaii Photo Rental came across my facebook feed.
"Confirmed, we have four Canon 5D Mark III cameras available to rent starting on Friday of this week."
"Krap." I said to myself, "I'm going to want to play with it for a weekend." I had been telling myself since the March 2, 2012announcementof this highly anticipated camera that there was no need for me to buy it. There was absolutely no reason I would need a new camera, and that my 5D Mark II's were more than enough. I decided, what the hell. I'll rent it for the weekend. First, A little back story on what I shoot with currently. Switching over from a set of 1D bodies (1D3/1D2N) I was a little hesitant about dropping 5k on two new cameras. Not to mention I was switching over from zooms to strictly primes. The 5D2 sensor was and is something very beautiful. It s a full frame21.1mp CMOS sensor that has the ability to produce some amazing quality, vibrant images, both during the day and night. My good friend Luke Sharrett posted on SportsShooter.com one day about how the full frame sensors "Attracted better light, and better moments." I laughed, but felt it was pretty true. After purchasing two, they became my main work horse cameras, while I would occasionallysupplementthem with a 1D Mark IV. Some things that bothered me about the 5D2's were the responsiveness of the AutoFocus (AF) system. The slow 3.9 frames per second. and the beautiful 3.0-inch Clear View LCD (920,000 dots/VGA) screen that 'lied' to me about image sharpness. But like all things, the 5D Mark II's, like all other cameras, are tools. Tools that we use for our respective jobs. Wether it be an assignment for a magazine, newswire, newspaper, commercial client, or a wedding. The Cameras we use are tools used to create images. Simple as that. The 5D's helped me understand composition, timing, and training myself to accept the 'shortcomings' and limitations of the tools we use, and to do my best training myself to overcome these limitations and not let them affect the way I performed my job.

First Impressions

I walked into the tiny shop on Waialae and was greeted by Josh and Natalie's smiling faces. "KENT!" they exclaimed (at least in my head that's what it was like) As Natalie processed my order, Josh was placing four 5D Mark III's on top of his display case, prepping for a photo that he would later post to Facebook, driving traffic and more potential customers to rent a 5D from them. He handed me the 5D I would be spending the weekend with. After spending almost two years with 5D Mark II's always in my hand, I instantly noticed the weight difference betweent he two cameras. Yeah, to some the 5D Mark II felt like a toy but that didn't matter much to me. However, the 5D Mark III, weighing in at 33.5oz. compared to the 28.6oz of it'spredecessor felt solid and comfortable in my grip. Not a brick like the 1D Mark IIN was, but not super light like my dad's 7D.

The New Menu, and Button layout

[caption id="attachment_812" align="alignnone" width="950" caption="Menu images CanonUSA"][/caption] First things first. I needed to setup the camera to my usual 5D settings so I could be at least comfortable with it and focus on creating images with it while putting it through it's paces. Canon did a great job redesigning and reimplementing the menu. Making it a bit more intuitive and a bit easier to use. However, being a typical guy, I didn't bother to read the manual, and found myself wasting time trying to find where specific settings are. If you want to read the manual, you can get a copy here. Courtesy of Canon Rumors. Having to work on Friday, I didn't have much of a chance to go out with the camera and test it out, so I used it as a good opportunity to familiarize myself with it's controls and custom functions. Saturday, I was itching to get out and shoot.

Taking it out for a spin

Having gotten to setup the camera as closest to theoperationsof my 5D2's I proceded to head out the door with Geena and my good friend Jaysonto Waikiki for some good ol' feature hunting. Below are a set of images from that Saturday. [caption id="attachment_827" align="alignnone" width="950" caption="Trying something different. However, the 5D3 files have some crazy dynamic range."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_824" align="alignnone" width="950" caption="Waikiki Sandtanline?"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_822" align="alignnone" width="950" caption="Reflections come out pretty nicely. but thats easy to do with the 5D2 as well...Files have crazy dynamic range though..."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_823" align="alignnone" width="422" caption="Another Reflection. This time I cropped a Horizontal to a vertical. Files are really nice."][/caption] [caption id="attachment_828" align="alignnone" width="950" caption="Metallic Bros."][/caption] First impressions? having 61 Autofocus points rocked my sox off. Thank god they didn't stick with the same AF system...AGAIN. Having walked around Waikiki for about 3 hours, I though I gave the 5D a good runthrough. Sometimes I noticed were that instances of missed moments due to the camera not locking focus and not firing at the moment I wanted it to. It might be a custom function I missed due to the new menu layout, not to mention, I really don't understand the new AF menu system (See the menu picture from earlier.) [caption id="attachment_825" align="alignnone" width="950" caption="Missed the focusing on this moment. The White dude in the center was right where the focus point was."][/caption] Probably shoulda read the Manual. Another issue I had was that Canon changed the way you zoomin to check pictures' sharpness, and the way you digitally zoom in to check your focus in live view mode. Aside from revamping the menu, they changed soe of the buttons around. I love that they added a 'Rate' button. But, right now at least, I don't enjoy using the Magnifying glass button to check focus while shooting video. High ASA Having the ability to shoot at high ASAs/ISOs was something I really appreciated with the 5D Mark II. With the Mark III, it gets even better. Check the images below. [caption id="attachment_820" align="alignnone" width="950" caption="University Avenue. ASA16000 f/2, 1/200th sec. 7:15pm"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_826" align="alignnone" width="950" caption="Salt Lake Parking Lot. ASA16000 f/1.2 1/500th."][/caption] I spent two nights pushing the limitations of the Mark III's high ASA capabilities, and there is only one work to really describe it.

SMOOTH.

Silky smooth, buttery smooth...Canon really out did themselves with the high asa capabilities on this camera. Honestly though, I can't think of a reason why a consumer would need to have such amazeballs ASA capabilities, but for journalism/editorial work, it can and will come in handy. It's like practically seeing in the dark. Canon finally added in HDR and Multiple Exposure to its cameras. Check out the quick handheld HDR I shot on my way to judge some high school portfolios. I didn't really do athoroughtesting like you see on some sites like Engadget (Review by Zach Honig), I had the camera for a couple of days and didn't have any gigs lined up to really test it out. I took it out for a casual spin and the opinion mentioned above is merely what I got from playing with it for a couple days. To sum it up, the 5D Mark III is everything I had wished for in the 5D Mark II. Solid build and feel, great autofocus, and superb image quality. Would I rent this camera over the 1D Mark IV? Probably. 9 out of 10 times I'll say yes to the 5D3 over the Mk4, and for renting it for3 Days for $185USD, is better than spending$109/day for a 1F Mark IV. All in all, its a great camera that will be loved by professionals and consumers alike. But, you don't have to take my word for it. Give it a test run, rent it from Hawaii Photo Rental today! Will I buy one? YES. So yeah, Canon did it again. They found yet another way to separate me from my 'hard earned' money. They created probably one of the best cameras I've had the pleasure of using. I felt the two 5D2's I had were perfect for what I was doing. Now, I WANT a 5D Mark III.

Thanks Canon, for ruining my weekend.

All Images and text, unless otherwise noted, 2012 Kent Nishimura - Honolulu, HI based photojournalist | www.kentnishimura.com

item.title: Has it been a year already?
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded:
Remembering Chris Hondros and Tim Hetherington. Barnstorm XXIV, The Eddie Adams Workshop. It almost feels like it was yesterday. I woke up to my phone buzzing like crazy. I wasreceivingreports of two photojournalists either killed or hurt really really badly in Libya. I quickly jumped out of my bed and ran to my desk, waking up my computer from sleep. I quickly loaded twitter, The New York Times, Facebook and other news sites to see what information I could find. A huge lump had formed in my throat. Photojournalists Chris Hondros and Tim Hetherington had been reported killed in Misurata, Libya.

"Oh, Shit!"

I quickly opened an email browser and opened gmail. I needed to email Cory. Did I know Chris Hondros? Did I know Tim Hetherington? No. I didn't But what I would find out later that year isthatboth of them were scheduled to be apart of the 24th Eddie Adams Workshop, which I would be attending in the fall of 2011. Mr. Hondros was a alumni of Barnstorm, having attended as a student 18 years prior, and returned as a member of the black team. Mr. Hetherington was a prominent film maker. His more noteable work is Restrepo. Catch it on Netflix if you get a chance. It's...wow. How Mr. Hondros ties to me is that he and my real good friend and colleague Cory Lum were roommates at the workshop, back in the early 90s. As far as I know, Cory was the only other person from Hawaii to attend the workshop before me. Memories of Chris Hondros. Photographs from Barnstorm VI: (L) Mr. Hondros and Joe Rosenthal. (R) Mr. Hondros framing a photograph of his at the McDonalds in Liberty. Photographs by Cory Lum, Used with Permission. Cory shared stories of him and Mr. Hondros at the workshop, and how they kept in touch after they had parted ways. Cory would return home to Hawaii and his budding career as a Hawaii based photojournalist, working for the Honolulu Advertiser, and later freelancing for the European Pressphoto Agency, Getty Images, The New York Times, and the LosAnglesTimes. Meanwhile, Mr. Hondros would spend much of his career as a staffer with Getty Images, covering all of the major conflicts on the 1990s. I didn't know Mr. Hondros or Mr. Hetherington personally, but somehow I had been affected by their passing. I felt like I didn't have a right to be sad, to be so broken-hearted that they're gone. That night, after it was confirmed that both Mr. Hondros and Hetherington had lost their lives in Libya I drove up to the Tantalus lookout where I saw on the rock wall overlooking Honolulu and began to think about life, and about the events of the day. Flash forward to October 2011 during the Eddie Adams Workshop. My team's photo editor was Newsweeks' Jamie Wellford, who was a close friend of the late Mr. Hetherington, gave a deep speech about Mr. Hetherington and Hondros and how much they wanted to attend that years barnstorm. We held a small ceremony for those who lost their lives up at Eddie's farm. The atmosphere was heavy and solem, and a lot for me to take in. Tonight I will toast a beer in their honor. Aloha Mr. Hondros, Aloha Mr. Hetherington. If you are interested in donating to the Chris Hondros Fund, click here. Also, please visit Time Hetherington's site for more information. **All content, unless otherwise noted is copyright 2012 Kent Nishimura, Honolulu Hawaii based Photojournalist | www.kentnishimura.com**

item.title: A quiet frame
item.dc:creator: kentnishimura
item.content:encoded: My grandmother stands at the front door of her house looking out towards the street on May 13, 2012 in Honolulu, Hawaii. I recently purchased a Fuji X Pro 1 as my happy snap funtime camera. It's quite, its not as obtrusive as a DSLR, and the Fuji glass is amazingly sharp. The photograph above was from a JPEG file that was resized for web. That's all I did to it...wild. If you wanna check out this tiny beast of a camera, you can rent it as well as a 18mm f/2 lens from Hawaii Photo Rental.
